text: But it seems they only use go I hope their engineering and community story works out for them. It‚Äôs one thing to be technical excellent (which they still have to prove!) but it‚Äôs two other things to extend the projects metaphors to programmers and it‚Äôs users as sustainable culture.

elements.text: But it seems they only use go I hope their engineering and community story works out for them. It‚Äôs one thing to be technical excellent (which they still have to prove!) but it‚Äôs two other things to extend the projects metaphors to programmers and it‚Äôs users as sustainable culture.

text:
I post the whole text here to read: ‚ÄúThe modern operating system only implemented 2 metaphors for builders to extend: the file and the application. 
What if they also implemented ‚Äúevent‚Äù, ‚Äúplace‚Äù, ‚Äúperson‚Äù, ‚Äúfeed‚Äù abstractly: letting tools that the user invites into their life collaboratively extend those core connected metaphors as well? 
My operating system should understand that ‚ÄúMessenger‚Äù is a medium by which I ‚Äúsend‚Äù ‚Äúmessages‚Äù to ‚Äúpeople‚Äù and that would allow it to join messages to a person across all mediums. 
Instead every ‚Äúapplication‚Äù reinvents the same metaphors over and over in incompatible ways. The user doesn‚Äôt want applications, they want extensions. 
An ‚Äúapplication‚Äù invents metaphors to manipulate, whereas an ‚Äúextension‚Äù extends them. 9/10 apps I use should be extensions to metaphors the operating system provides. 

 
Maybe builders and tools should be able to present extendable metaphors to the operating system. This is an interesting idea Web3 is doing. NFTs are not in the ethereum spec, they were implemented later by people but then shared ‚Äî the ERC721 token standard is a ‚Äúmetaphor‚Äù. 
But honestly, I‚Äôm not as interested in this yet. Common, open, shared metaphors for ‚Äúperson‚Äù, ‚Äúplace‚Äù, ‚Äúevent‚Äù, ‚Äúmessage‚Äù, and ‚Äúrelationship‚Äù would move us so far forward before even considering the long tail of remaining metaphors. 
I‚Äôd love to see @Apple and @Microsoft build these metaphors into their products. Consider iOS 15‚Äôs focus modes, it‚Äôs great I can own & control my digital experience by writing rules about who can reach me when I‚Äôm in ‚Äúwork mode‚Äù, but those rules don‚Äôt work. 
They don‚Äôt work because the iPhone, the smartest device in the world, doesn‚Äôt comprehend that a phone number and a SnapChat account could possibly represent the same person. Contacts isn‚Äôt an application, it‚Äôs a metaphor that other tools and services need to extend. 
The water is muddy with Apple because they will always want their first party experiences to perform better than third party ones because that‚Äôs how they sell devices. That‚Äôs sad. 
Your operating system should be incentivized to be the layer of metaphors, and then apps and extensions arrive to make those metaphors useful and bring them to life. 
I mentioned Web3 earlier, that‚Äôs not the solution here. Web3 implements some fascinating metaphors around identity, governance, and currency; but, the solutions here need to be faster, more private, and be more customizable. 

 
Or maybe Web3 is a movement that encompasses building common metaphors regardless of implementation ‚Äî and blockchain is just the first platform of many that will be used to that end. That‚Äôs a fascinating prospect. 
In the end, though, the point I want to convey is that applications should collaboratively extend common metaphors to enrich my life, not incompatibly recreate the wheel over and over and over. ‚Äú <https://twitter.com/adamtowerz/status/1443505907208392707|https://twitter.com/adamtowerz/status/1443505907208392707>

text: For everyone looking for an practical entry into web3 I can highly recommend this 8 week course: <https://kernel.community/en/|https://kernel.community/en/>

attachments.text: A peer-to-peer, lifelong learning community of the most talented individuals in web3

text: Twitters take at web3 or these metaphors is blue sky and Kei kreutler has this nice piece about ‚Äúinventories not identities‚Äù <https://twitter.com/keikreutler/status/1443894493057519628?s=21|https://twitter.com/keikreutler/status/1443894493057519628?s=21>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/keikreutler|@keikreutler>: i'll be part of the first bluesky twitter event <https://twitter.com/bluesky|@bluesky>

the topic is decentralized identity, and i'll be sharing thoughts from my essay "inventories, not identities" on the cultural possibilities collective, pseudonymous, & cross-platform accounts create <https://blog.gnosis.pm/inventories-not-identities-7da9a4ec5a3e>

text: I've talked with the Anytype folks, they _are_ trying to do something interesting: sort of a modular app environment built on top of IPFS (so local-first/can sync between devices with only a local network). They're starting with sort of a Notion-alike initial functionality to make sure that it can work as a product for early adopters
